abstract: Looking for ways to ease the complicated relationship between newspaper publishers and giant search engines like Google and Yahoo.
snippet: Looking for ways to ease the complicated relationship between newspaper publishers and giant search engines like Google and Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: NEWSPAPER publishers and other content producers have a complicated relationship with giant search engines like Google and Yahoo. They simultaneously try to curry favor with these sites, hiring people known as optimizers with magical incantations to make articles show up high on the results pages and drive traffic, all the while grumbling that maybe, perhaps, it isn’t fair for the search engines to make copies of their material  so that it can be searched or appear on aggregation sites like Google News  without compensation.

abstract: Although it is the largest handset maker in the world, Nokia has languished in the American market, hurt by its refusal to adapt its strategy to the market’s idiosyncrasies.
snippet: Although it is the largest handset maker in the world, Nokia has languished in the American market, hurt by its refusal to adapt its strategy to the market’s idiosyncrasies.
lead_paragraph: ESPOO, Finland  When Google announced plans in October to revolutionize the software of cellular phones, few were more eager to hear the details than the industry veterans at Nokia. They still are.

headline.main: Nokia Pushes to Regain U.S. Sales in Spite of Apple and Google
headline.print_headline: Nokia Pushes to Regain U.S. Sales in Spite of Apple and Google

abstract: Of the four broadcast networks, ABC is the only one that has not announced plans for its January and February schedule, which will probably have to change because of the writers’ strike. In Sunday’s New York Times, Michael Cieply wrote that the alphabet network “could significantly increase its reality programming from the five to six hours it has run this fall”:
lead_paragraph: Of the four broadcast networks, ABC is the only one that has not announced plans for its January and February schedule, which will probably have to change because of the writers’ strike. In Sunday’s New York Times, Michael Cieply wrote that the alphabet network “could significantly increase its reality programming from the five to six hours it has run this fall”:

headline.main: Strike Schedule: What Will ABC Do?
